tweets.content:
My DMs are flooded with questions about @rustlang ü¶Ä resources so here it is!
Here‚Äôs a quick spotlight series: one post for each creator, their X handle + YouTube channel + what they‚Äôre best for.

Jon Gjengset
X: @jonhoo
YouTube: Jon Gjengset
Best for: Deep dives into Rust internals, async, concurrency, and the legendary ‚ÄúCrust of Rust‚Äù series. If you want to master advanced Rust concepts, start here.

Rust Nation UK
X: @RustNationUK
YouTube: Rust Nation UK
Best for: Full conference talks, workshops, and interviews with top Rust developers. Great for keeping up with the Rust community and latest trends.

Semicolon
X: @shivansh7201
YouTube: Semicolon
Best for: Beginner-friendly Rust tutorials and hands-on coding walkthroughs. Ideal for absolute beginners.

Rustfully
X: @rustful
YouTube: Rustfully
Best for: Short, focused Rust tutorials perfect for bite-sized learning and quick tips.

Orhun Parmaksƒ±z
X: @orhunp
YouTube: Orhun Parmaksƒ±z
Best for: Rust shorts, CLI tools, and productivity hacks. Great for quick learning and inspiration.

Harkirat Singh
X: @kirat_tw
YouTube: Complete Rust Bootcamp
Best for: Full-length Rust bootcamp (6+ hours, Hindi/English mix). Perfect for new devs and anyone who wants a structured, hands-on marathon.

Solandy
X: @HeyAndyS
YouTube: Solandy
Best for: Solana-specific Rust tutorials, especially for DeFi and NFT use cases.

Rust Planet
YouTube: Rust Planet
Best for: Practical Rust projects and ecosystem exploration.

Rust Videos
X:@rustlang
YouTube: Rust Videos
Best for: Official Rust community curation conference talks, meetups, and lectures from all over the world.

Copenhagen Rust Community
YouTube: Copenhagen Rust Community
Best for: Community-driven channel with talks from Copenhagen‚Äôs Rust meetups and events.

Code to the Moon
X: @CodeToTheMoons
YouTube: Code to the Moon
Best for: Rust explained simply ideal for those who want to see code in action.

Francesco Ciulla
X: @FrancescoCiull4
YouTube: Francesco Ciulla
Best for: Wide-ranging dev content, including Rust, with a focus on making tech accessible and fun.

Jeremy Chone
X: @jeremychone 
YouTube: Jeremy Chone
Best for: Rust, backend engineering, and system design.

Dario Lencina
YouTube: Dario Lencina
Best for: Practical Rust and systems programming; helpful for those coming from C/C++ backgrounds.

Trevor Sullivan
X:@pcgeek86
YouTube: Trevor Sullivan
Best for: Automation, DevOps, and using Rust for scripting and tooling.

Rust Programming Tutorials Playlist
YouTube: Rust Programming Tutorials
Best for: Step-by-step Rust tutorials for beginners.

Rust Nation UK Playlist
X: @RustNationUK
YouTube: Rust Nation UK Playlist
Best for: Curated talks and workshops from Rust Nation UK events.

Thanks to all these individuals and communities for creating such valuable content and sharing their knowledge with the Rust and Solana community.
Save/bookmark for later will keep updating as I find more gems. Tag your favorite creators if I missed anyone!

tweets.author: AdityaPlusp

tweets.content:
LSR ‚Äì Lightweight Simple Rent (aka Less Stupid Rent)lol

This is a straightforward idea that keeps things fully composable.

Instead of requiring users to prepay rent or worry about account cleanup, rent is just paid incrementally when accounts are accessed by the fee payer using the account. Simple.

So if an account is used once per epoch, it stays active and uncompressed without needing any extra maintenance. The rent is covered by whoever uses it.

For example, take a standard 168-byte token account that would normally require 0.02 SOL in rent. Under LSR, the expected per-epoch cost would be just 0.000005714 SOL, assuming rent prices stay constant.

And here's the cool part: as more accounts are compressed and the total state size drops, rent will actually get even cheaper over time.

tweets.author: AdityaPlusp

tweets.content:
Going to sleep after diving into Solana‚Äôs Alpenglow upgrade from a great Helius article. It‚Äôs replacing Proof of History making things way faster & cheaper by moving voting off chain. Super impressive!  

But I still wonder will moving votes off chain risk more centralization? 

 Key points:  
- Finality: 12s ‚Üí ~150ms (near instant) 
- Off-chain voting = less congestion, faster consensus 
- Rotor = 1 hop block broadcast 
- Lower costs ‚Üí more validators 
- Simple 400ms block times, no cryptographic clock wait 

Link üëá
tweets.author: AdityaPlusp

tweets.author: AdityaPlusp

tweets.content:
It‚Äôs 7:30 AM and I‚Äôm finally going to sleep :) 

Spent the night deep diving into ShredStream insane speed boost over gRPC.

- About 100ms to 200ms faster
- Mid-slot data
- Access before the block is even complete

I thought gRPC was the fastest turns out ShredStream is way quicker.

Just finished writing a Rust ShredStream listener + parser (using protos for decoding)

Now I just need a premium gRPC provider that supports ShredStream for an end-to-end test.

Until then‚Ä¶ good night :D

tweets.content:
TEEs vs zk-SNARKs

‚Üí TEEs: Hardware-based, super fast, relies on trusted machines.
‚Üí zk-SNARKs: Math-based, no hardware needed, fully verifiable.

Two paths to keep your data private on-chain - which side are you on?

tweets.content:
Here‚Äôs mine Web3 ‚Üí Solana ‚Üí Fullstack Blockchain Developer Roadmap

JavaScript / TypeScript ‚Üí Async/Await ‚Üí Fetch API / WebSockets

‚Üí Blockchain Basics (Wallets, Keys, Signatures, Transactions)
‚Üí Cryptography (ECDSA, Hashing, Ed25519)
‚Üí Token Standards (ERC-20 / SPL) ‚Üí NFT Standards (ERC-721 / Metaplex)
‚Üí Choosing a Chain (Ethereum vs Solana) ‚Üí Why Solana (Speed, Fees, Parallel Execution)
‚Üí Client-Side Dev with solana/web3.js ‚Üí Wallet Adapters (Phantom, Solflare,Backpack)
‚Üí Reading On-Chain Data ‚Üí Sending Transactions ‚Üí Token Transfers
‚Üí SPL Token Program ‚Üí Associated Token Accounts ‚Üí Metadata Program
‚ÜíUse client side libraries Build simple dApps or wallet extensions for practice
‚Üí On-Chain Indexing (Helius, RPC/Webhooks)
‚Üí Try to understand others contract transactions like pumpfun and raydium on explorers
‚Üí Use prebuild launchpad sdks and make a simple trade bot using solana libraries solana/web3js and solana/spl-tokens
‚Üí Rust Fundamentals ‚Üí Solana Program Architecture
‚Üí Anchor Framework Basics ‚Üí Program Accounts ‚Üí PDA & Seeds
‚Üí Testing Contracts (Mocha, Anchor Tests) ‚Üí Local Validator & Devnet
‚Üí Cross-Program Invocations (CPI) ‚Üí Sysvars ‚Üí Rent
‚Üí Fullstack dApp (React / Next.js + Anchor + web3.js)

‚Üí Advanced Solana:
   ‚Ä¢ Jito / MEV Protection
   ‚Ä¢ Lookup Tables
   ‚Ä¢ Transaction Bundling
   ‚Ä¢ Parallel Execution & Priority Fees
   ‚Ä¢ Alpenglow

‚Üí Tokenomics & Launchpads (Pumpfun, Raydium, Coinflict)
‚Üí NFT Mints & Candy Machine v3 ‚Üí Auction House Program
‚Üí Deployment: Solana CLI ‚Üí Mainnet
‚Üí Monitoring & Logging (Solana Explorer, Sig Verify, RPC Health)
‚Üí CI/CD for dApps & Programs
‚Üí Infra: Docker ‚Üí Kubernetes ‚Üí GPU Nodes (for AI-integrated dApps)
‚Üí Cloud (AWS/GCP) for RPC & Indexers

tweets.author: AdityaPlusp
AdityaPlusp

tweets.content:
Story Time:

I met a friend in the first year of college ‚Äî a naturally talented coder. He had been coding since Class 11, and by the time we entered our first year, he already knew all the core programming concepts: loops, functions, data structures, OOP ‚Äî everything. While the rest of us were still learning how to write a basic "Hello World" program, he was already solving college-level assignments with ease.

It‚Äôs been 5 years since then. With 7 years of non-stop coding experience under his belt, you‚Äôd expect him to be working in a top tech company or building innovative products, right?

But no.

He‚Äôs currently working as a college teacher, earning ‚Çπ20,000 per month ‚Äî the same job he joined last year. He‚Äôs not involved in any major projects, no startups, no open-source contributions, no tech community activities. He spends his time helping students with assignments, taking classes, and that‚Äôs it.

It‚Äôs surprising. A guy with that level of coding knowledge, someone who lives in VS Code, is now stuck in a routine job with no technical growth or exploration.

It just goes to show ‚Äî skill alone isn‚Äôt enough. Without direction, ambition, and real-world application, even the most talented people can end up underutilized.
tweets.author: AdityaPlusp

tweets.content:
How I lost more than xx0 $SOL trading memecoins ‚Äî and mistakes you should not repeat 

- Overtrading is a trap. sitting out is also a position.

- Don‚Äôt suffer alone ‚Äî talk to frens when you lose. helps more than you think.

- Never selling - is a myth. take profits. it's not diamond hands, it's delusion.

- 1 out of 100 memecoins actually runs. the rest? rugs or slow bleeds.

always check:
‚ÄÉ- bubblemap
‚ÄÉ- top 10% holders
‚ÄÉ- funding wallets
‚ÄÉ- snipers
‚ÄÉ- utility (if any lol)
‚ÄÉ- if the team is actually building or just vibing

Red flags are red flags. don‚Äôt convince yourself otherwise.

Make sure you don‚Äôt pay the same tuition fee. @solana @pumpdotfun @bonk_inu
